lines.text: I was born when she kissed me. I died when she left me. I lived a few weeks while she loved me.
There's no sacrifice too great for a chance at immortality.

[rolls his eyes]
Yes sir.
[last lines]

[tearfully]
I lived a few weeks while you loved me. Goodbye, Dix.
Before I started to go to work at Paul's, I used to think that actors made up their own lines.
When they get to be big stars, they usually do.
Why didn't you call for a cab? Isn't that what a gentleman usually does under the circumstances?
Oh I didn't say I was a gentleman. I said I was tired.
You know, you're out of your mind - how can anyone like a face like this? Look at it...
[leans in for a kiss]
I said I liked it - I didn't say I wanted to kiss it.
Remember how I used to read to you?
Uh huh. Since then, I've learned to read by myself.
Go ahead and get some sleep and we'll have dinner together tonight.
We'll have dinner tonight. But not together.

[Dixon has replied with sarcasm to Lochner's questions]
You're told that the girl you were with last night was found in Benedict Canyon, murdered. Dumped from a moving car. What's your reaction? Shock? Horror? Sympathy? No - just petulance at being questioned. A couple of feeble jokes. You puzzle me, Mr. Steele.
Well, I grant you, the jokes could've been better, but I don't see why the rest should worry you - that is, unless you plan to arrest me on lack of emotion.

[noting the geography of their apartments]
You know, Ms. Gray, you're one up on me - you can see into my apartment but I can't see into yours.
I promise you, I won't take advantage of it.

[wryly]
I would, if it were the other way around.
It was his story against mine, but of course, I told my story better.
What does it matter what I think? I'm the guy who tried to talk Selznick out of doing "Gone with the Wind"!
You know, I got married.
Why?
Oh, I don't know. I guess she had a couple of bucks to spare.
Anything you want to make you happy?

[whispers into his ear]
I wouldn't want anyone but you.
I didn't expect you to give me more information... but certain facts contradict your original statement.

[flatly]
I wish you'd say what you mean.
Yes, let's do that. On the night of the Atkinson murder, you looked at Dixon Steele and said you didn't know him.
I didn't.
Since then, you and he have been inseparable.
He's writing a script. I'm doing the typing.
Do you receive a salary for this?
No. I'm doing it for love.

[surprised]
Are you in love with Mr. Steele?
For the record, I am in love with Mr. Steele.
Are you going to be married?

[pause]
If we do, I'll send you an invitation - after all, it was you who first introduced us to each other.

[after summarizing a novel she's read]
And, you know, there are lots of little plots and things I didn't even tell you about!
Thank you.
There's no sacrifice too great for a chance at immortality.
[a non-sequitur said to a confused waiter, in the bar scene]
Yes sir.
[being polite, then rolling his eyes as he walks away]
Dix Steele ! How are you? Don't you remember me?
Sorry, can't say that I do.
You wrote the last picture I did... at Columbia
Oh, I make it a point to never see pictures I write.
[referring to the book Dixon is supposed to adapt into a screenplay]
Oh I think it'll make a dreamy picture, Mr. Steele. What I call an epic.
And what do you call an epic?
Well, you know - a picture that's REAL long and has lots of things going on.
It must be WONDERFUL to be a writer!

[sarcastically]
Oh, thrilling!

[to Laurel]
I've been looking for someone a long time... I didn't know her name or where she lived - I'd never seen her before. A girl was killed, and because of that, I found what I was looking for. Now I know your name, where you live, and how you look.

[on a scene in Dix's script]
I love the love scene - it's very good.

Well that's because they're not always telling each other how much in love they are. A good love scene should be about something else besides love. For instance, this one. Me fixing grapefruit. You sitting over there, dopey, half-asleep. Anyone looking at us could tell we're in love.
Oh, I love a picnic. Acres and acres of sand and all of it in your food.
Stop griping. Just lie still and inhale.
What, sand?
No, air - and don't let it go to your head.

[to Capt. Lochner]
Yesterday, this would've meant so much to us. Now it doesn't matter... it doesn't matter at all.

You know, when you first walked into the police station, I said to myself, "There she is - the one that's different. She's not coy or cute or corny. She's a good guy - I'm glad she's on my side. She speaks her mind and she knows what she wants."
I also know what I don't want - and I don't want to be rushed.
A man wants to apologize to you...
Do you look down on all women or just the ones you know?
I was pretty nice to you.
No, not to me. But you were pretty nice.
Remember, angel, in the beginning was the land. Motion pictures came later.
What's the matter, don't you like to talk anymore?
Not the people who have my number.

[on hearing a voice at the front door]
My friend Charlie, who speaks but poetry and borrows but money.

I did not catch names of character but this is a great quote. he is the older actor who enters the restaurant/club dressed in a tux, with tails, cape and top hat. After this scene, he joins Bogart & Gloria Grahame and the old Agent at their table to discuss Dix's new script. The hostess or hat check girl says to him]
Mr. X, you forgot to change your costume.

[the older gentleman replies]
This is not a costume, ignorant wench; it's the formal attire of a gentleman.
Well, he's exciting because he isn't quite normal.
Maybe us cops could use some of that brand of abnormality. I learned more about this case in five minutes from him than I did from all of our photographs, tire prints and investigations.
Nobody can call me the things he did.
A blind, knuckle-headed squirrel. That's REAL bad.
Considering that you've never met Mr. Steele, you pay quite a bit of attention to him.
Hmm-hmm. I have at that.
Do you usually give such attention to your neighbors?
No.
Were you interested in Mr. Steele because he's a celebrity?
No, not at all. I noticed him because he looked interesting - I like his face.
You annoy me!
If I do, it isn't intentional.
I love Dix. It upsets me terribly that you suspect him, even for second.
Not for a second, for the last three weeks. He's our most logical suspect.

[Entering kitchen as Dix is sectioning a grapefruit]
What happened to the grapefruit knife?
It was crooked and I straightened it.
Fool, it's supposed to be curved!
What? Wonder what they'll think of next!

[to Laurel about Dix]
You knew he was dynamite. He has to explode sometimes.

[as Mel enters the house he intoduces him to Laurel]
Oh, come in. Mr. Lippman, my agent.
[He intoduces Laurel to Mel]
Miss Gray, my alibi.

[to black man hosing down the sidewalk in front of the florist shop]
Say, do me a favor, will you, pal?
Yes, sir.
I want to send two dozen white roses to a girl.
Yes, sir. Do you want to write a card?
No, there's no card. Her name's Mildred Atkinson.
Mildred Atkinson. Yes, sir. What's her address?
I don't know. Look it up in the papers. She was murdered last night.
Yes, sir.
It's much easier to get people's names into the papers than to keep them out.

[verbally recreating a vehicular strangulation]
You get to a lonely place in the road, and you begin to squeeze...
Why can't he be like other people?

Like other people - would you have liked him? You knew he was dynamite - he has to explode sometimes! Years ago, I tried to make him go and see a psychiatrist. I thought he'd kill me! Always violent. Well it's as much a part of him as the color of his eyes, the shape of his head. He's Dix Steele. And if you want him, you've gotta take it all, the good with the bad. I've taken it for 20 years and I'd do it again.
Remind me to buy you a new tie.
[in a sarcastic retort to a comment by his agent Mel, in the bar scene]
